questions.text: Which of the following best describes the core principle of the McNaughten Rule in determining legal insanity?

options.label: A
options.text: The accused was suffering from a delusion at the time of the offence.

options.label: B
options.text: The accused could not control their actions due to a mental disorder.

options.label: C
options.text: The accused could not understand the nature or wrongness of their actions due to a mental defect.

options.label: D
options.text: The accused had a history of psychiatric illness before the offence.

questions.correct_answer: C. The accused could not understand the nature or wrongness of their actions due to a mental defect.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a rule for criminally insane individuals?
Identify the FALSE statement on civil responsibilities of the insane from the following options:

options.label: A
options.text: A contract is void if one party lacks mental capacity at the time of the agreement.

options.label: B
options.text: Mentally ill individuals can serve as guardians for their own property.

options.label: C
options.text: The Hindu Marriage Act permits annulment if one party is mentally unfit at the time of the ceremony.

options.label: D
options.text: A holographic will must be entirely in the testator's handwriting and meet specific validity criteria.

questions.correct_answer: B. Mentally ill individuals can serve as guardians for their own property.

questions.text: Which of the following best differentiates hallucination from illusion in perception disorders?

options.label: A
options.text: Hallucination occurs with external stimuli, while illusion occurs without any stimuli.

options.label: B
options.text: Hallucination is a false perception without an external stimulus, while illusion is a misinterpretation of a real external stimulus.

options.label: C
options.text: Hallucination and illusion are both voluntary perceptions of external objects.

options.label: D
options.text: Hallucination is always visual, while illusion is always auditory.

questions.correct_answer: B. Hallucination is a false perception without an external stimulus, while illusion is a misinterpretation of a real external stimulus.

questions.text: Match the following types of delusions with their appropriate descriptions. 1. Othello Syndrome a) Belief that one is dead or putrefying. 2. Cotard Syndrome b) Belief that a spouse is unfaithful. 3. de Clérambault’s Syndrome c) Belief of being infested with parasites. 4. Ekbom Syndrome d) Belief that a higher-status person loves the individual.
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Delusion of Grandeur : Belief of being very important or wealthy, often seen in mania.
  • ↳ Delusion of Grandeur
  • ↳ Delusion of Poverty : Conviction of impending loss of all material possessions.
  • ↳ Delusion of Poverty
  • ↳ Delusion of Infidelity/Jealousy (Othello Syndrome) : Belief that a spouse is unfaithful, leading to extreme actions. Males are more commonly affected.
  • ↳ Delusion of Infidelity/Jealousy (Othello Syndrome)
  • ↳ Delusion of Reference : Belief that media and others refer to the individual, often negatively.
  • ↳ Delusion of Reference
  • ↳ Delusion of Persecution : Belief that one is being harmed or poisoned by others, leading to potential violence.
  • ↳ Delusion of Persecution
  • ↳ Delusion of Influence/Control : Belief that one's thoughts and actions are controlled by external forces.
  • ↳ Delusion of Influence/Control
  • ↳ Hypochondriacal Delusion : Persistent fear of having a serious illness based on unrealistic interpretations.
  • ↳ Hypochondriacal Delusion
  • ↳ Delusion of Self-Reproach/Criticism : Self-blame for imagined offences, potentially leading to suicide.
  • ↳ Delusion of Self-Reproach/Criticism
  • ↳ Nihilistic Delusion : Belief that one does not exist or that the world does not exist, often seen in depression.
  • ↳ Nihilistic Delusion
  • ↳ Delusion of Doubles (Doppelganger) : Patients believe that another person has been physically transformed into themselves.
  • ↳ Delusion of Doubles (Doppelganger)
  • ↳ Erotomania (de Clérambault’s Syndrome) : Belief that someone of higher social status is in love with the individual.
  • ↳ Erotomania (de Clérambault’s Syndrome)
  • ↳ Capgras Syndrome : Belief that a close person has been replaced by an exact double.
  • ↳ Capgras Syndrome
  • ↳ Fregoli’s Phenomenon : Strangers are identified as familiar people.
  • ↳ Fregoli’s Phenomenon
  • ↳ Ekbom Syndrome (Delusions of Parasitosis) : Belief of being infested with parasites.
  • ↳ Ekbom Syndrome (Delusions of Parasitosis)
  • ↳ Folie à Deux : Shared delusions between two people.
  • ↳ Folie à Deux
  • ↳ Cotard Delusion/Syndrome : Belief that one is dead, does not exist, is putrefying, or has lost blood or internal organs.
  • ↳ Cotard Delusion/Syndrome

questions.text: A 45 y/o man is brought to the psychiatric clinic by his wife. He claims that his wife has been replaced by an impostor who looks exactly like her but is not his real wife. He reports feeling anxious and confused about why others cannot see the difference. His medical history includes a previous diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25 y/o woman presents to the dermatologist with intense itching and anxiety, convinced that tiny insects are crawling on her skin. She frequently inspects her body and applies various lotions to prevent what she believes are infestations, although no evidence of insects or bites is found on examination. She is aware that her fear may be exaggerated, but she cannot stop feeling anxious about it. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Acrophobia

Fear of heights (Option C)

Acarophobia

Fear of mites/insects (Option B)

Claustrophobia

Fear of confined spaces

Needle Phobia

Fear of injections

Algophobia

Fear of pain

Xenophobia

Abnormal fear of strangers

Gamophobia

Fear of marriage/relationships

Zoophobia

Fear of animals

Kleptomania

Compulsive stealing

Dipsomania

Compulsive drinking of alcohol

Pyromania

Urge to set fires

Mutilomania

Desire to harm animals

Oniomania

Compulsive shopping

Trichotillomania

Compulsive hair-pulling

Suicidal Impulse

The urge to commit suicide, often triggered by intoxication

Homicidal Impulse

Urge to commit homicide, linked to chronic intoxication

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Mental Healthcare Act (MHCA) 2017 is NOT true?

options.label: A
options.text: The Act aims to align mental healthcare services with the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows for both voluntary and involuntary admissions, with specific protocols for each.

options.label: C
options.text: The MHCA 2017 came into effect on July 7, 2020, replacing the previous Mental Health Act of 1987.

options.label: D
options.text: It introduces advance directives that enable individuals to express their treatment preferences in advance.

questions.correct_answer: C. The MHCA 2017 came into effect on July 7, 2020, replacing the previous Mental Health Act of 1987.
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Overview of the Act : Purpose : Aims to provide comprehensive mental healthcare and services, aligning with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (2006). (Option A ruled out) Implementation Date : Enacted on July 7, 2018, replacing the Mental Health Act of 1987.
  • ↳ Overview of the Act
  • ↳ Purpose : Aims to provide comprehensive mental healthcare and services, aligning with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (2006). (Option A ruled out) Implementation Date : Enacted on July 7, 2018, replacing the Mental Health Act of 1987.
  • ↳ Purpose : Aims to provide comprehensive mental healthcare and services, aligning with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (2006). (Option A ruled out)
  • ↳ Purpose
  • ↳ (Option A ruled out)
  • ↳ Implementation Date : Enacted on July 7, 2018, replacing the Mental Health Act of 1987.
  • ↳ Implementation Date
  • ↳ Key Provisions : Rights Protection : Focuses on protecting and promoting the rights of individuals during mental healthcare delivery; ensures treatment in the least restrictive environment. Admission Procedures : Specifies detailed protocols for voluntary and involuntary admissions; all admissions require notification to a Mental Health Review Board (MHRB) for stays exceeding 30 days. (Option B ruled out) Advance Directives : Introduces advance directives and nominated representatives, allowing individuals to express treatment preferences in advance . (Option D ruled out)
  • ↳ Key Provisions
  • ↳ Rights Protection : Focuses on protecting and promoting the rights of individuals during mental healthcare delivery; ensures treatment in the least restrictive environment. Admission Procedures : Specifies detailed protocols for voluntary and involuntary admissions; all admissions require notification to a Mental Health Review Board (MHRB) for stays exceeding 30 days. (Option B ruled out) Advance Directives : Introduces advance directives and nominated representatives, allowing individuals to express treatment preferences in advance . (Option D ruled out)
  • ↳ Rights Protection : Focuses on protecting and promoting the rights of individuals during mental healthcare delivery; ensures treatment in the least restrictive environment.
  • ↳ Rights Protection
  • ↳ Admission Procedures : Specifies detailed protocols for voluntary and involuntary admissions; all admissions require notification to a Mental Health Review Board (MHRB) for stays exceeding 30 days. (Option B ruled out)
  • ↳ Admission Procedures
  • ↳ 30 days.
  • ↳ (Option B ruled out)
  • ↳ Advance Directives : Introduces advance directives and nominated representatives, allowing individuals to express treatment preferences in advance . (Option D ruled out)
  • ↳ Advance Directives
  • ↳ express treatment preferences in
  • ↳ advance
  • ↳ (Option D ruled out)
  • ↳ Implementation Challenges : Resource Limitations : Acknowledges limited mental healthcare resources in India; provides a 10-year timeline for meeting international standards in human resource development for mental healthcare. Transition from Previous Legislation : Introduces stringent involuntary admission procedures compared to MHA 1987, requiring legal formalities that may delay treatment.
  • ↳ Implementation Challenges
  • ↳ Resource Limitations : Acknowledges limited mental healthcare resources in India; provides a 10-year timeline for meeting international standards in human resource development for mental healthcare. Transition from Previous Legislation : Introduces stringent involuntary admission procedures compared to MHA 1987, requiring legal formalities that may delay treatment.
  • ↳ Resource Limitations : Acknowledges limited mental healthcare resources in India; provides a 10-year timeline for meeting international standards in human resource development for mental healthcare.
  • ↳ Resource Limitations
  • ↳ Transition from Previous Legislation : Introduces stringent involuntary admission procedures compared to MHA 1987, requiring legal formalities that may delay treatment.
  • ↳ Transition from Previous Legislation
  • ↳ Conclusion : The MHCA 2017 is a progressive step towards improving mental health care in India. Success depends on effective implementation despite existing resource constraints.
  • ↳ Conclusion
  • ↳ The MHCA 2017 is a progressive step towards improving mental health care in India. Success depends on effective implementation despite existing resource constraints.
  • ↳ The MHCA 2017 is a progressive step towards improving mental health care in India.
  • ↳ Success depends on effective implementation despite existing resource constraints.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the psychiatric unit after assaulting a bystander without provocation. He reports months of auditory hallucinations with threatening voices, disorganized thoughts, and paranoid delusions. He is distressed, has poor hygiene, has a flat affect, and shows no signs of manipulation or substance abuse. What is the most likely explanation for his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Feature

True Insanity (Option A)

Feigned Insanity (Option B)

Onset

Gradual

Sudden

Motive

Absent

Present (e.g., after a crime)

Predisposing Factors

Usually present (e.g., family history)

Absent

Signs and Symptoms

Uniform, specific

Variable, exaggerated

Activity

Careless, persists even when unobserved

Only present when observed

Mood

Excited, depressed, fluctuating

Overacted to appear abnormal

Facial Expression

Peculiar, vacant, worried

Frequently changing, exaggerated

Insomnia

Present

Inconsistent, resolves in a day or two

Exertion

Can endure exertion, fatigue

Breaks down after short exertion

Habits

Dirty and filthy

Clean, not neglected

Dressing

Careless

Reasonably proper

Skin and Lips

Dry, harsh

Normal

Tongue

Coated

Clean

Repeated Examinations

Doesn't mind

Resists for fear of detection

questions.text: A 25 y/o man is brought to the ED after being found wandering outside his home late at night, appearing confused and disoriented. He has no recollection of the events that occurred while he was outside. This behaviour is consistent with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Sleep apnea

It occurs in the deeper sleep phases, primarily affecting stage N3 and REM sleep.

Narcolepsy

It involves skipping initial sleep phases and directly entering REM sleep, leading to persistent daytime sleepiness. This results in reduced N3 deep sleep and irregular sleep patterns.

REM sleep disorder

It involves acting out dreams with vocalizations and movements due to disrupted muscle atonia during REM sleep.

Somnambulism or sleepwalking

It occurs during non-REM sleep, typically in the N3 phase. This is when individuals can make purposeful movements without acting out their dreams, which happens in REM sleep.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Psychosis?

options.label: A
options.text: In psychosis, contact with reality is often preserved.

options.label: B
options.text: Individuals with psychosis typically exhibit empathy

options.label: D
options.text: An organic causative factor is present.

questions.correct_answer: D. An organic causative factor is present.
questions.explanation:
Features

Psychosis

Neurosis

1. Contact with reality

Lost

Preserved (Option A ruled out)

2. Interpersonal behavior

Marked disturbance in personality and behaviour

Preserved

3. Empathy

Absent

Present (Option B ruled out)

4. Insight

Absence of understanding of current symptoms

(insight absent)

Symptoms are recognized as undesirable

(insight present) (Option C ruled out)

5. Organic causative factor

Present 

Absent

6. Symptoms

Delusions, illusions and hallucinations

Usually physical or psychic symptoms

7. Dealing with reality

Capacity is grossly impaired

Preserved

8. Examples

Dementia, schizophrenia

Anxiety, phobia, depression, conversion disorder.
